channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Videos Show Increasingly Aggressive Federal Crackdown in Minneapolis
item.description: Arrests and aggressive tactics by ICE and the Border Patrol, many seen on viral videos, have intensified the frustration and fear among residents.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller and Jazmine Ulloa

item.title: ICE Arrested Dozens of Refugees in Minnesota and Sent Them to Texas, Lawyers Say
item.description: The refugees, many of them from Somalia, had passed security screenings before coming to the United States. The Trump administration has vowed to “re-examine thousands of refugee cases.”
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. Border Patrol agents clashed with community members after federal immigration officers crashed into a vehicle in south Minneapolis to ask about the driver’s immigration status on Monday.

item.title: Six Prosecutors Quit Over DOJ Push to Investigate Renee Good’s Widow
item.description: Joseph H. Thompson, a career federal prosecutor who was the acting U.S. attorney for Minnesota last year, was among those who resigned as the Justice Department sought to examine the woman’s supposed ties to activist groups.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Ben Brewer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph H. Thompson, a federal prosecutor, has led the prosecution of fraud in social services programs in Minnesota.

item.title: Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey, Who Cussed Out ICE, Is No Stranger to Crisis
item.description: Mayor Jacob Frey, a Democrat, has clashed with his party’s activist wing. His response to ICE has won him new respect at home and new foes in Washington.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Jacob Frey in his office at City Hall in Minneapolis.

item.title: In Secret Testimony, Republicans Derided Trump’s Stolen Election Claims
item.description: The testimony, part of the derailed Georgia election interference case, makes clear how dismissive some senior Republicans were of claims of widespread fraud in the 2020 election.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
item.category: Georgia Criminal Case Against Trump (2020 Election)
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Transcripts of secret grand jury testimony indicate that President Trump’s efforts to overturn his defeat in the 2020 presidential election exasperated and alarmed a number of senior Republicans.

item.title: Senator Says Prosecutors Are Investigating Her After Video About Illegal Orders
item.description: It is unclear what possible crime might involve Senator Elissa Slotkin, a Democrat, who has warned in dire terms about the dissolution of American democracy.
item.dc:creator: Greg Jaffe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Elissa Slotkin of Michigan, a former C.I.A. officer, organized a video with five other Democratic lawmakers in which they urged military service members to resist illegal orders.

item.title: Trump Raises Middle Finger at Heckler in Michigan Ford Factory Tour
item.description: A White House spokesman said the president “gave an appropriate and unambiguous response.”
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump touring a Ford factory in Dearborn, Mich., on Tuesday.

item.title: Iran’s Leaders May Survive Protests. But Anger Will Likely Persist.
item.description: Its security forces have brutally defended the Islamic Republic, but the protests show that many Iranians consider it stagnant and ideologically hollow.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.media:description: Some parts of Tehran saw heavy damage during protests in recent days.

item.title: As Iran’s Government Tries to Quell Protests, Accounts of Brutal Crackdown Emerge
item.description: As many as 3,000 feared dead as witnesses describe government forces firing on unarmed protesters.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Farnaz Fassihi, Sanam Mahoozi and Sanjana Varghese
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: via Reuters
item.media:description: An image taken from social media and verified by The New York Times shows people looking for relatives as bodies piled up outside Tehran’s forensics laboratory on Sunday.

item.title: Starlink Users in Iran Get Free Internet Access, Nonprofits Say
item.description: Under a near-total communications blackout, users of Elon Musk’s satellite service have gotten online without paying, organizations that work on tech issues said.
item.dc:creator: Natallie Rocha
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.media:description: The Iranian government has cracked down on protests like this one in Tehran last week with a communications blockade.

item.title: A Timeline of Protests in Iran
item.description: Amid a near-total communications blackout, witness footage trickling out of Iran paints a picture of how the country’s largest uprising in decades spread — and turned deadly.
item.dc:creator: Monika Cvorak and Sanjana Varghese
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: China Announces Record Trade Surplus as Its Exports Flood World Markets
item.description: China’s surplus reached $1.19 trillion last year, a 20 percent increase from 2024, as Beijing kept the currency weak and pursued self-reliance to replace imports.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The production line at a car factory in Hangzhou, China, in October. Exports to the United States fell, but rose to much of the rest of the world.

item.title: Mark Carney Heads to Beijing to Discuss Canada-China Relations as U.S. Outlook Darkens
item.description: The prime minister is seeking new markets for Canadian goods and to mend relations with China after years of deep acrimony between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Yoan Valat
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada and his advisers have said that he is seeking a pragmatic thawing of Canada’s relationship with China.

item.title: Jimmy Carter, the Man From Plains, Had a Passion for Painting
item.description: Amy Carter, the daughter of former president Jimmy Carter, selected paintings and memorabilia for two Christie’s sales. The prices might surprise you.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small

item.title: Blowback Builds Over Criminal Investigation of Powell
item.description: Trump allies fear that the inquiry into the Fed chair could complicate the process of replacing him this year.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport, Colby Smith, Glenn Thrush and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Global economic leaders have expressed concern about the credibility of the world’s most important economic institution after the Justice Department’s announcement of an investigation into the Federal Reserve chair, Jerome H. Powell.

item.title: In a Risky Gambit, Trump Tries Brute Force to Lower Prices
item.description: To assuage cost-weary voters and combat inflation, the president has resorted to a mix of threats and punishments, targeting companies and policymakers alike.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: There is seemingly no lever that President Trump appears unwilling to pull, as he looks to ease the economic strains on voters now anxious about the state of the country.

item.title: China’s Coal Ban Improved Air Quality, but Villagers Are Paying the Price
item.description: China banned the burning of coal for heat around Beijing, but natural gas subsidies have run out, leaving many villagers vulnerable in dangerously cold weather.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of a village in Quyang County, in northern China, soak up the midday sun to try to warm up and reduce their heating costs.

item.title: Saks Files for Bankruptcy as Department Stores Fight for Survival
item.description: The parent company of Saks, Neiman Marcus and Bergdorf Goodman struggled with debt, designers and customers in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Kim Bhasin, Vanessa Friedman and Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis/Reuters
item.media:description: Saks Fifth Avenue in New York City was founded in 1924 as a jewel of American retail. The store stands across the street from Rockefeller Center.

item.title: What the Bankruptcy of Saks Means for You
item.description: Answers to this and other questions about the financial crisis in America’s biggest luxury department store.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman and Jacob Bernstein
item.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis/Reuters
item.media:description: Saks Fifth Avenue, one of the country’s most storied luxury department stores, has filed for bankruptcy protection.

item.title: Bill and Hillary Clinton Refuse to Testify in Epstein Inquiry
item.description: The couple escalated their battle with Representative James R. Comer, the chairman of the Oversight Committee, who said he would move to hold them in contempt of Congress.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative James R. Comer has repeatedly threatened to hold Bill and Hillary Clinton in contempt if they failed to appear for live depositions behind closed doors.

item.title: Extreme Weather Events Hit Around the World in 2025
item.description: Last year was Earth’s third hottest globally, but temperature is just one measure of climate change’s influence.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Palisades Fire burning along the Pacific Coast Highway early last January.

item.title: Supreme Court Appears Inclined to Allow States to Bar Transgender Athletes
item.description: The outcome of a pair of cases on Tuesday could affect laws in 27 states that prohibit transgender girls from joining girls’ and women’s sports teams.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Becky Pepper-Jackson, who sued to join her middle school’s girls’ cross-country team when she was 11, asserted that her state’s statute violates Title IX.

item.title: Mr. Mamdani Goes to Albany, a Backbencher No More
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani of New York City returned to the State Capitol for the first time since taking office, underscoring the shifting political winds since his victory.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes
item.media:credit: Lauren Petracca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani shakes hands with a former colleague, Assemblyman Michael Durso, at the State Capitol in Albany.

item.title: Lower Bills and ‘Go Bills’: 8 Takeaways From Hochul’s State of the State
item.description: In her address on Tuesday, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York focused on affordability, while pushing for nuclear power and new restrictions on religious protests.
item.dc:creator: Grace Ashford and Benjamin Oreskes
item.media:credit: Cindy Schultz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Even as Gov. Kathy Hochul embraced portions of the agenda of New York City’s new mayor, Zohran Mamdani, she also underscored the limits of their partnership.

item.title: Mayor Mamdani Names Transit Veteran as Taxi Commissioner
item.description: Midori Valdivia would head the Taxi and Limousine Commission, overseeing more than 115,000 for-hire vehicles. The mayor said drivers deserved a “forceful champion.”
item.dc:creator: Winnie Hu, Stefanos Chen and Wes Parnell
item.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis for The New York Times
item.media:description: The yellow cab industry has begun to recover from the pandemic.

item.title: Scott Adams, Creator of the Satirical ‘Dilbert’ Comic Strip, Dies at 68
item.description: His chronicles of a corporate cubicle dweller was widely distributed until racist comments on his podcast led newspapers to cut their ties with him.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:credit: Lea Suzuki/The San Francisco Chronicle, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Scott Adams in 2014 in his home office in Pleasanton, Calif. For more than 30 years, his comic strip, “Dilbert,” chronicled the absurdities of the high-tech workplace and skewered management.

item.title: The Ayatollahs’ Antisemitism Has Undone Iran
item.description: A regime that would rather pursue a perpetual jihad against the Zionist enemy than feed its own people will eventually fall.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens

item.title: Something Bad Is Brewing on Venezuela’s Border
item.description: An armed guerrilla group stands emboldened to challenge the authority of the Colombian state — and U.S. ambitions in Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Dickinson
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times

item.title: Crane Falls on Passenger Train in Thailand, Killing at Least 22
item.description: The railway authorities said there were almost 200 people on the train when the accident happened in Nakhon Ratchasima Province, northeast of Bangkok. Dozens were injured.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Ministry of Transport, via Reuters
item.media:description: A crane fell on a passenger train in Nakhon Ratchasima province in Thailand on Wednesday.

item.title: Claudette Colvin, Who Refused to Give Her Bus Seat to a White Woman, Dies at 86
item.description: Her defiance of Jim Crow laws in 1955 made her a star witness in a landmark segregation suit, but her act was overshadowed months later when Rosa Parks made history with a similar stand.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Dudley M. Brooks/The The Washington Post, via Roseboro Holdings and The Colvin Family Legacy/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Claudette Colvin in 1998. When she was ordered to move to the back of a bus in 1955, she refused: “History had me glued to the seat,” she said.

item.title: Eric Adams Hawked a Crypto Coin. A Day Later, $1 Million Was Missing.
item.description: Officials tied to the venture insisted no money had been stolen, but the withdrawal caused the coin’s value to plunge.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos and David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:credit: Kent J. Edwards for The New York Times
item.media:description: The crypto coin backed by Eric Adams quickly soared to a market capitalization of nearly $600 million, but then plunged after the mysterious withdrawal.

item.title: Kiefer Sutherland Is Arrested After Assaulting Ride-Share Driver, Police Say
item.description: The actor also made “criminal threats” toward the driver, according to the Los Angeles police.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Aude Guerrucci/Reuters
item.media:description: Kiefer Sutherland was released from custody after posting a $50,000 bond, according to county jail records available online.
